subject: Re: [junit] assertTrue
msgSnippet: I must concur. I wonder, why the change to assertTrue from assert ? The old model seemed more logical: assert is the atomic action and common assertions
messageBody:
I must concur. I wonder, why the change to "assertTrue" from "assert"? The
old model seemed more logical: "assert" is the atomic action and common
assertions are built in terms of "assert", so it makes sense that "assert"
be the base name and "assertX" be a shorthand for "assert(X)".

Subject: [junit] assertTrue




I just moved up to JUnit 3.7, and I'm beginning to convert existing code
to use assertTrue instead of assert.

Does anyone else find it odd to write something like:

assertTrue(!someCondition);

I had no problem with assert(!someCondition), but it reads funny with
assertTrue().

Would it make sense to add a corresponding assertFalse(someCondition) to
JUnit? I know it is redundant in a sense, but I think it would
communicate better.

Randy
